Type.Name: Assembly
Type.ThreadingSafetyStatement: This type is safe for multithreaded operations.

summary.para: Defines a , which is a reusable, versionable, and self-describing building block of an application.

remarks.para: An assembly is a reusable, versionable, self-describing deployment unit for types and resources. Assemblies are the fundamental units of deployment, and consist of collections of types and resources that are built to work together and form logical units of functionality.
An assembly consists of the following two logical elements:

item.term: The sets of types and resources that form some logical unit of functionality.
A manifest, which is the metadata that describes how the types and resources of an assembly relate and what they depend on to work properly.

remarks.para: The following information is captured in an assembly manifest:

item.term: An assembly's identity includes its simple name (also called its weak name), a version number, an optional culture if the assembly contains localized resources, and an optional public key used to guarantee name uniqueness and to "protect" the name from unwanted reuse.

Assemblies contain types and resources. The manifest lists the names of all the types and resources that are visible outside the assembly, along with information about where they can be found within the assembly.

Each assembly explicitly describes other assemblies that it is dependent upon. Included in this dependency information is the version of each dependency that was present when the manifest was built and tested. In this way the "known good" configuration is recorded and can be reverted to in case of failures due to version mismatches.
As an assembly is being built, the assembly records the set of permissions that the assembly requires to run.

para.block: For additional information about assemblies, see Partition II of the CLI Specification.

Docs.summary: Get the absolute path from which the assembly was originally loaded.
Docs.value: Absolute path from which the assembly was originally loaded.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance object CreateInstance(string typeName)

Docs.param: The name of the type to locate.

summary.para: Locates the specified type from this assembly and creates an instance of it using case-sensitive search.

returns.para: An instance of representing the type, or if is not found.

public static string CreateQualifiedName (string assemblyName, string typeName);

Docs.summary: Returns a for the Entry Point in the assembly if it exists.
Docs.value: object for the Entry Point in the assembly if it exists.
Docs.remarks: If there isn't an entry point in the assembly, the object is null.

MemberSignature.Value: .property string FullName { public hidebysig virtual specialname string get_FullName() }

summary.para: Gets the full name of the assembly.

value.para: A containing the full name of the assembly.

block.para: The full name is returned in the following format:

The section of the string contains the textual name of the assembly, and is equivalent to the name of the file into which the assembly manifest is compiled. This name does not change even if the file with the assembly manifest is later renamed. For additional information about assembly manifests, see Partition II of the CLI Specification.
For information on the information in the full name of a , see .

The is a containing the value of the public key token in hexadecimal format. A indicates that the current assembly is private. For additional information about public keys and public key tokens, see Partition II of the CLI Specification.

para.block: This property is used by the method.

example.para: The following example demonstrates using the property to get the full name of an assembly compiled into a file named "HelloWorld".

Docs.summary: Gives the Assembly of the method which invoked the currently running method.
Docs.returns: Assembly of the method which invoked the calling method.
Docs.remarks: If method A invokes method B, and method B calls Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly() then the result is the assembly of method A. In other words, this is useful for things like performing reflection on a user of some utility class you are writing. It does NOT return the "current" assembly of your own code! For that, try Assembly.GetAssembly(this)

Docs.returns: The entry assembly. If invoked from a secondary AppDomain, this call returns null.

Docs.summary: Returns the location of the loaded assembly if the assembly was loaded from disk. If the assembly was loaded from memory, returns an empty ("") string.

summary.para: Returns a representation of the value of the current instance.

returns.para: A representation of the current instance. The string takes into account the current system culture.

remarks.para: This method returns the of the current assembly.

example.para: The following example demonstrates the use of the method in an assembly compiled into a file named "HelloWorld".
